abstract.para: This book covers the use of the CMandrill extension & plugin for Joomla. It does not cover any other extension available on compojoom.com .

section.title: Transactional emails
section.para: Transactional emails are emails sent to an individual based on some action. It could be:

listitem.para: an action they took directly
an action they were the target of
an inaction on their part (reminder to login into a website)

section.para: For example if a user registers on a website, most of the time he will get a confirmation or welcome mail. This is a transactional email.

section.title: Introducing Mandrillapp.com
section.para: In April 2012 Mailchimp introduced a new transactional email service called Mandrill. Mandrill is using the same optimized delivery engine that Mailchimp uses for the delivery of bulk newsletters – slightly modified for one-to-one email. The core features of Mandrill are:

listitem.para: Uses Mailchimp's awesome email delivery engine
Tracks opens and clicks
Automatically adds Google Analytics tracking data to the URLs in the mail
Has pretty, visual reports of the email results
Allows you to tag the emails and see your stats filtered by tag

section.para: Since the above description might not help you much, let us try with an example.

Let us imagine that after registering on website X, we don't get the confirmation mail. What do we do? We contact the website owner and say - sorry, but we didn't receive the email. Let us imagine that we are the owner of website X - what do we do when a customer is telling us that he didn't receive the mail? We scratch our head and we say - look at your spam folder. But is the email really in the spam folder, was it actually sent? Is it still in the process of delivery or did it magically disappear from the face of the internet? In the past we did not have a simple way to know that, but now that has changed thanks to Mandrill. You can look at the emails being sent from your Joomla website, you can look at open/click rates and you can always know if a mail was delivered or it bounced back. This is what the Mandrill service is all about - giving you the peace of mind that your customers are receiving your emails & the bonus of knowing if they actually open them and engage with the content.

section.title: Introducing CMandrill for Joomla
section.para: Since you normally need to be a programmy nerd to use the service MailChimp asked us to create an integration for Mandrill's API into Joomla. Back in April 2012 we came up with a simple plugin, that allowed you to just provide your API key and after that all e-mails* send by Joomla are going to be sent trough the Mandrill API. Since then we've used the plugin ourselves on compojoom.com and with each day we started to love the Mandrill service even more. That's why we decided that a plugin is great, but making a whole extension would allow us to even better integrate with the Mandrill API and make Joomla's emails just awesome!
With the CMandrill extension you'll be able to:

listitem.para: Send emails through the Mandrill API optimised for speed
Look at the most important stats (send, receive, bounce rates) directly from your Joomla backend
Configure a global HTML template for emails
Create HTML templates for specific components by specifying the class & function names that send the mail

section.para: * All extensions that use the standard Joomla API for sending mails will continue to function as normal and the mails will be send trough Mandrill. If you are using extensions that have their own Mail classes, then those extensions will continue to function as normal, but they won't use the Mandrill API

chapter.title: Installation and Updates
chapter.para: Installing the Mandrill plugin for Joomla is easy it is not in any way different than installing any other Joomla!™ extension/module/plugin on your site. You can read the complete instructions for installing Joomla!™ extensions on the official Joomla help page .Throughout this chapter we assume that you are familiar with these instructions and we will not duplicate them.

section.title: Getting the installation packages
section.para: You can download the latest installation packages by visiting our site at https://compojoom.com. (you need to be login) In the download menu you will see the CMandrill menu item. Click on it. The latest releases are listed with the newest release always on top. Click on the release number and then download the ZIP package.

section.title: Compatibility
section.para: The CMandrill extension for Joomla is currently compatible with Joomla 2.5 & 3.0

section.title: Updating to the latest version
section.para: The plugin uses the standard update routine in Joomla. All you need to do is to go to Extensions -> Extension Manager -> Update in your Joomla backend. Then click on "Find Updates" if a new version of the plugin is available you will be able to update by selecting it and clicking on the "Update" button

chapter.title: Using the CMandrill extension for Joomla
chapter.para: The zip package of CMandrill will install both the extension and the plugin. After the installation you need to navigate to components -> CMandrill and then access the options of the extension. Once you provide your Mandrill API key, you need to navigate to Extensions -> Plugin manager and activate the "System - Mandrill" plugin.

section.title: Options
section.para: To access the options screen navigate to Components -> CMandrill and then click on the Options tag.
In the basics tab you have the following parameters:

API key - In the API key field provide your Mandrill API key (on the day of writing that documentation the API key could be found by clicking on the settings button (top right) at the mandrillapp.com page (you need to be logged in to see it))
Use https - The use https option defines if the plugin should communicate with Mandrill server through an SSL connection or not. We recommend to set this option to yes if your hosting has the necessary PHP SSL libraries for this.
In the Permissions tab you can specify which user group is allowed to access the backend of the extension.

section.title: Dashboard
section.para: CMandrill's dashboard is showing your most important email delivery stats right in the backend of Joomla. On the dashboard you can see your sent, delivered data for the last 7 days or all time stats. You also have a list with the top 100 most clicked urls in your emails.

section.title: Templates
section.para: In the templates view you'll be able to create a global HTML template that is going to be used when sending emails through Mandrill. Further more you can create templates just for specific extensions. For example you can have a global template that is used by all extensions, but for com_users you can have a customised template that gives newly registered users a coupon code along with their registration.

note.para: The HTML templates should be created directly in Mandrill. In CMandrill you just assign those templates to specific components, views or tasks.

section.title: Creating a template
section.para: On the template view click the new button. You'll be presented with a form that you need to fill out and save.
Fields:

listitem.para: title - enter a title for this HTML template. The title is only visible in the backend and is used to help you figure out what the template is actually for.
Status - the status of the template can be either publish or unpublished. Unpublished templates won't be used when sending emails
Start publishing & Finish Publishing - if you specify a timeframe here the template will be only used when the timeframe is met
Mandrill Template - from this drop down field select the Mandrill template that this template is using.
Component - Use global if this template is meant to be used for the whole website. Use other if you are defining a template for a specific task
Class name - the php class name that is sending the mail
Function name - the php function in the class that is sending the mail

note.para: You may be wondering - how do I find the class name and function name. Well if you are developer, you could always use the your favorite code editor and dig into the code. On the other hand there is a much easier way! Just trigger the task that you need a custom template for. Once you do, look at the activity tab in mandrill . You'll notice that the sent email has 2 tags -> one starting with class_ and the other one starting with function_ . Those are your class name and function name. Just copy the part after the underscore and you are ready to go!

example.title: Example - custom template for the Registration view
example.para: 1. On your site navigate to the registration view.
2. Fill out all the details and click register.
3. Login in mandrillapp.com and look at the activity tab. The mail that was sent about the registration has the following tags: class_UsersModelRegistration & function_register
4. Now go to CMandrill -> templates -> new. For component select other, for class name enter UsersModelRegistration and for function name enter register. Save the template
5. That's it! Now the joomla registration emails will be sent using the template that you've specified!

chapter.title: The Plugin
chapter.para: When you install the CMandrill extension we also install the "System - Mandrill" plugin. This plugin is actually used to send the emails through the Mandrill API, so you'll need to enable it once you've provided your API key in the component's settings.

note.para: Once you enable the plugin, make sure that everything is working by executing an action on your site that sends an email. The email that you receive then should be coming from mandrill. (look at the sender's name)

chapter.title: The CMandrill library
chapter.para: Since version 3 the CMandrill component comes with a library called CMandrill. This library is a fork of the official PHP Mandrill wrapper. Our goal with this library is to make it compatible with the Joomla Coding standards and make it easy for developers to use it in their own projects based on the joomla framework, or in CLI scripts. If you are interested in the library, check out the github repository!

section.title: Sending limits
section.para: Depending on your Mandrill account there are different sending limits that apply for you. If you are a free user then this limit is currently 12 000 emails per month. For more information on sending limits please refer to Mandrill's help pages.

The current implementation of the plugin checks how many emails you have send for the day and how big your sending limit is. If you have reached your sending e-mail then the plugin will fall back to the standard JMailer class and will send the mails according to the settings that you have specified in your Global Configuration (Joomla's global configuration. Accessible through Site -> Global Configuration -> Server -> Mail Settings)

section.title: CC emails
section.para: If a Joomla extension tries to send an email that has the CC option set, then the plugin will fall back to the standard JMailer class and won't use the Mandrill API.

section.title: What happens with rejected mails?
section.para: In some situations the Mandrill API won't send the mail and will return a rejected status for it. In this case the plugin will try to send the mail to the recipient again, but this time using the standard JMailer class.

section.title: Logging
section.para: The plugin uses the standard Joomla JLog class to log errors and warnings. The logs are saved in the folder configured in your Joomla's Global Configuration. The logs are split by Month. You can expect them to identify situations in which the plugin was not able to send the email using Mandrill's API and has fallen back to the standard JMailer class.

section.title: Events logged
section.para: The plugin logs following events:

listitem.para: Use of CC option for sending emails
Daily sending quota exceeded
Queued messages
Rejected messages
Unsupported attachments

section.title: Tags
section.para: For each Mail we try to add the following tags:

listitem.para: option - identifies the Joomla component sending the email
view - identifies the view of the component sending the mail
task - identifies the task that is executed by the component sending the mail

section.para: Each of this tags is added only if we are able to identify it.

section.title: Attachments
section.para: Currently the Mandrill API supports only attachments with the mime type image/*, text/* and application/pdf. If your Joomla site is sending emails that contain other attachments, then the plugin will recognise this and will fall back to the standard JMailer class.

section.title: Email HTML templates
section.para: You can have only 1 global template, but you can have as many custom HTML templates as you wish.

section.title: How do we determine which template to use?
section.para: When we are sending the mail we are trying to find out if you have a template that matches all criteria - class name and function name. If we find such a template we are going to use it. If we don't, then we will use the global template - if one is provided. If you don't have a global template, then we will send the mail as plain text.

section.title: What modifications are made to the content of HTML mails
section.para:
If we determine that we need to use an HTML template, then we need to slightly modify the content of the mail. Most mails in Joomla are sent as plain-text. But if you are using an HTML template you want this plain text to be properly formatted. So that is why when we need to send an HTML template and we find out that the text is in plain-text we parse it and add
where necessary & we also change HTML links to html link . Those small modifications make sure that the mail will look fine in the user's inbox.
